article.title: Effects of bulk viscosity and hadronic rescattering in heavy ion collisions at RHIC and LHC

choices: The temperature dependence of shear viscosity over entropy density ratio
The temperature dependence of bulk viscosity over entropy density ratio
The temperature dependence of energy density

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main effect of including bulk viscosity on the observables shown in this figure?
choices: It increases the multiplicity of all hadron species.
It decreases the average transverse momentum of all hadron species.
It significantly impacts the anisotropic flow coefficients of charged hadrons.
It has a negligible effect on the observables shown.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the impact of varying the switching temperature (Tsw) on the multiplicity and average transverse momentum of identified hadrons. What can be concluded about the sensitivity of protons to Tsw compared to pions and kaons?
choices: Protons are much less sensitive to changes in Tsw than pions and kaons.
Protons exhibit a similar level of sensitivity to changes in Tsw as pions and kaons.
Protons are significantly more sensitive to changes in Tsw compared to pions and kaons.
The sensitivity of protons, pions, and kaons to Tsw cannot be determined from this figure.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares calculations with and without hadronic rescattering. What is the most prominent effect of including hadronic rescattering on the proton multiplicity?
choices: It significantly increases the proton multiplicity across all centralities.
It has a negligible effect on the proton multiplicity across all centralities.
It increases the proton multiplicity in central collisions and decreases it in peripheral collisions.
It decreases the proton multiplicity in central collisions and increases it in peripheral collisions.
